turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: No, but he heard firing, just east, less that a kilometer.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Thank him and tell him we're sorry about his loss.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: A machine gun.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Good luck, Captain.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't need it, I'm a cat, I've got five lives.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: The men said, nine.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: What do they know?  I had nine, but I feel through the ice when I was seven, my brother pulled me out.  Then I used one when a grenade landed in my foxhole in Sicily, it was a dud.  I figure one on the beaches, one on the cliffs and two getting here.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: That only leaves three.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Plenty.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: I wonder where they're going.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Same place we are.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: I'd like to stay, too, Captain.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You don't count.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: I can tell what the gunners had for dinner.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Those guns are close.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: What about our grenades?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Those are Tigers, they have six-inch armor, they don't even notice grenades.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Would they notice and eighty-eight?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sure, you got one?

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: The Germans do.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Upham, you've got to learn the difference between whining and griping.  You can't just rely on natural ability, you've got to study and practice.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: But, sir...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: There you go again, that's whining, that's not okay.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Goddamn it, sir...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: That's better, but you've still got a long way to go.  Talk to Reiben, he's a natural and works at it, he'll give you some pointers.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: What'd you say, Captain?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I teach English at Addley High School in Addley, Pennsylvania.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Captain, what about our deal?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I changed my mind.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: GO!

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Rolls his eyes, takes a breath. Scrambles into the gap.  The other five right behind.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: CAPTAIN, IF YOUR MOTHER SAW YOU DO THAT, SHE'D BE VERY UPSET!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I THOUGHT YOU WERE MY MOTHER.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Worked, didn't it?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You tryin' to get yourself killed?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't need to, the Krauts go that covered.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Caen?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I wish.  You and I are taking a squad up to Ramelle on a public relations mission.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You?  Leading a squad?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Some private up there lost three brothers, got a ticket home.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: What about the company?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Simpson.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Simpson?  Jesus Christ on a fucking pogo stick!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I want Reiben on B.A.R; Jackson with his sniper rifle; Beasley, demolition.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Beasley's dead.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Okay, Wade.  Translators?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Fresh out.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: What about Talbot?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Twenty minutes ago.  Miller Damn, I'll go see if I can find another one.  You get Reiben, Jackson and Wade, meet me at transport.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You get a translator, Captain?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I've got a line on one.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Now we've got a straight shot, due north, to Ramelle, twenty-six miles, two villages between here and there, St. Mere, then Bernay.  We'll take the jeep as far as we can, then go on on foot.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: We in radio contact with anybody up there?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Somebody put the wrong crystals in every one of the Hundred-and-First's radios the night before the drop, not one of them works.  We're going in blind.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: A fucking mess, two maybe three Kraut divisions, no fronts, no lines, the drops were completely fouled up, we've got little pockets of paratroopers all over the place, trying to hang on.  Command says we hold St. Mere, but north of that, it's all Krauts.  Even if Ryan's where he's supposed to be, he's more than likely dead.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Hell of a mission.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yep, hell of a mission.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Uh, Captain...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: PUSH!

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Uh, Captain...

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Got it, sir.  We gonna go take care of those eighty-eights?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: That's not what we're here for.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: He's right, Captain, it might be kind of dangerous for those flyboys.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Tell that to Private James Ryan. We've got our orders.  Let's go.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You ever going to open those letters? Miller keeps his eyes on the maps.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: It's not normal, not reading letters from home.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Since when have things been normal?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You got me.  Afraid of bad news?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Good news?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You think they'll be alright?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: They're fine.  As long as they can gripe, they'll be alright.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: And what about you?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: They guys here aren't going to be able to hold out until battalion shows up.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Nope.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Command isn't going to let them withdraw and the Germans sure as hell aren't going to let them surrender.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Three for three.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: If we stayed, we could make a difference.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You're kidding yourself.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You never know.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: I hope this boy Ryan is worth it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Now you're the one kidding yourself.  Hell of  a mission.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Yup, hell of a mission.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Makes you feel small, doesn't it?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: It doesn't take this.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: A couple of weeks.  It started in Portsmouth when they brought us down for loading.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Is it getting worse?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: No.  It comes and goes.  It stops when I look at it.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You may have to find yourself a new line of work, this one doesn't seem to agree with you anymore.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I'll be alright.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yeah?  What rule of thumb is that?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: How about I go right, sir?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: How about you take your position?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: How about...?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: How about you shut up and take your position?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: HOLD YOUR FIRE!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Rolls to his feet.  FIRE another BURST.  KILLS the last of the German riflemen.  Doesn't pause.  RUNS onto the field.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Pulls Wade's hands from the wound. Pours sulfa powder.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: About to pour his sulfa.  Sees the wound.  Stops.  Knows it's fatal.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: SHOVES THE NEEDLE into Wade's neck. Thick vein.  Pumps the morphine straight to Wade's brain.  Motions impatiently to Sarge.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: More morphine, hurry up, come on, come on...

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Hesitates.  Then drops his sulfa. Fumbles in his pack.  Finds the morphine.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Snatches the morphine from Sarge. Quickly and efficiently prepares a second shot.  He's done this before.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You alright?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Let's just find someplace.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: What was the name of that kid at Anzio, the one who got his face burned off?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Vecchio.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yeah, Vecchio, I couldn't remember his name, he was a good kid, remember how he used to walk on his hands and sing that song about the man on flying trapeze?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You know why I'm such a good officer? Because of my mother.  Have I ever told you about her?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Bits and pieces.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: She's the best poker player you ever saw.  My father used to go to these Saturday night games and lose his shirt.  Finally, my mother gave him an ultimatum, either she gets a regular seat at the table or she locks him in every Saturday night. He squawked and so did his buddies but after a while they gave in and from the first night she sat down, she never lost.  She could read those cocky bastards like they were playing open hands.  And he bluffs?  He had sixteen levels of bullshit.  Her eyes, the tone of her voice, her bets, her jokes, the way she sipped her coffee, she was a master.  She won more money on shit hands than anyone in the history of the game. Every Saturday night, my father would lose two, three hundred bucks and she'd win it all back and then some. And I'd stand there, glued to her shoulder, from the time I was five years old, watching every hand, every move, studying how she did it.  That's why I'm such a good officer, I can look at a man's face and tell you exactly what he's holding, and if it's a shit hand, I know just what cards to deal him.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: And what about your own hand?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: No problem.  A pair of deuces?  Less? So what?  I bluff.  It used to tear me apart when I'd get one of my men killed, but what was I supposed to do?  Break down in front of the ones who were standing there waiting for me to tell them what to do?  Of course not, so I bluffed, and after a while, I started to fall for my own bluff. It was great, it made everything so much easier.  Sarge Is that why your hand's been shaking?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: It could be worse.  You know the first thing they teach you at O.C.S.? Lie to your men.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Oh, yeah?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Not in so many words, but they tell you you can have all the firepower in the world and if your men don't have good morale, it's not worth a damn.  So if you're scared or empty or half-a-step from a Section Eight, do you tell your men?  Of course not.  You bluff, you lie.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: And how do you bluff yourself?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Simple, numbers.  Every time you kill one of your men, you tell yourself you just saved the lives of two, three, ten, a hundred others. We lost, what, thirty-one on the cliffs?  I'll bet we saved ten times that number by putting out those guns.  That's over three hundred men.  Maybe five hundred.  A thousand. Then thousand.  Any number you want. See?  It's simple.  It lets you always choose mission over men.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Except this time, the mission IS a man.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: That's the rub.  I liked Wade.  Who's Ryan?  If they're both standing in front of me and I have to shoot one or the other, how do I choose?  Look at my hand, there it goes again.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: John, I've got to tell you, I think you're about used up.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I think you're right, Keith.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You want me to take over?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: No, but if I get any worse, you'll have to relieve me.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Just what I want to do.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You know Wade was the eleventh of the twelve, you're the last one still alive.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't let yourself get killed, if you do, they might make me give back the medal and then I won't be able to lip off to colonels anymore.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: I'll do my best.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Thanks for drawing that machine gun off me.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: You're welcome, John.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: But, that's my personal brand of stupidity, I feel kind of proprietary about it, if you do it again, you're busted.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sarge, see what you can do to make those buildings inhospitable.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: What do you think?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Well, if we had ten times the men and a lot more ammo, we might stand a chance, but not against those tanks.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: What are we going to do?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: We're going to hope like hell the tanks were on their way somewhere else.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Uh, oh.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Out of the mouth of babes.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Reiben, I don't know what I'd do without you.  Sarge, keep Ryan close to you and alive.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Captain, can I put in for a transfer?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sure, meet me at the top, we'll start the paperwork.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Sir, what if they send some other company into Caen ahead of us while we're pinned down here?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't worry, we're the only Rangers this side of the continent, we've got to be first into Caen.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: So, you ever heard of employee discounts?  My uncle sells shoes, gets twenty-five percent off everything in the line, got a closet filled with the best looking shoes you ever seen.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Just picture some French number been spending all day, every day, making cream-colored, shear-body negligees with gentle-lift silk cups and gathered empire waists, what the hell you think she wears at night?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Reiben, how the hell do you know so much about lingerie?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Lingerie is my life, sir.  My mother's got a shop in Brooklyn, I grew up in it, from the time I could crawl, we carry Caen lingerie, it's the best there is, it's all I been thinking about since the invasion.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: There's a war on, good chance they're not still making lingerie in Caen.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Oh, Captain, they'll always make lingerie, it's one of the three basic needs of man -- food, shelter, silk teddies.  Miller Dream on, private.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I don't think so, Captain.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Stay at it until you get fire control.  Keep 'em down, wait for the navy.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Strides through the chaos, avoiding the passing vehicles.  He sees his men and walks toward them.  Reiben hurries up to Miller, pleading.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Please, sir, you can't take me to Ramelle, I gotta go to Caen, sir, please, I told you, they make Caen lingerie there, it's beautiful, it's the best there is, it's...oh, please, sir...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sorry, I need a B.A.R. man, you're the best.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: No, I'm not, Kaback is, honest.  Or what about Faulkner?  Or that little guy with the glasses?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Trust me, you're the best.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: But, sir...

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Captain, can I ask you a question?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sure, Reiben.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Where are you planning on putting Private Ryan, sir?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Captain, I gotta tell you, the irony of this mission is fucking killing me.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yeah, how so?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I should be on my way to Caen, sir. It's like Beethoven, the guy's one of the greatest composers ever lived and he goes deaf.  Go figure, I mean, who'd he piss off?  And here I am, the Beethoven of ladies foundation garments, one step away from Caen, the center of the known lingerie universe and instead, I'm going to Ramelle to save some fucking private who's probably already dead.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: There's to be a bright side, look for it.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Sir, you know what Ramelle is famous for?  Cheese.  The rest of the company is going to Caen and we're going to the goddamned cheese capital of France.  There is no bright side.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: There's always a bright side.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I'm listening, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Well, I, for one, like cheese.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: General Gavin is going to be very irritated at you, Captain.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Stands on the edge of the woods, almost in a trance.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Jesus Christ, he's a natural!

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Upham, are you sure you've never been in combat?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Captain, could you please explain the math of this mission to me?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sure, what do you want to know?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Well, sir, in purely arithmetic terms, since when does six equal one?  What's the sense in risking six guys to save one?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Ours is not to reason why.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Never mind, don't worry, we'll pick up this kid, high-tail it back to division, everything'll work out fine.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I'd much rather die in Caen than Ramelle, sir.  It's a personal thing.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Reiben, there's a fairly good chance you're not going to die at all.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Easy for you to say, sir.  Fucking James Ryan, I'd like to wring his fucking neck.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Well, maybe not the Captain, but the rest of us have mothers.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You have orders, too.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Reiben, what's the matter with you? I don't gripe to you.  I'm a captain. There's a chain of command.  Griping goes one way, up, only up, never down.  You gripe to me, I gripe to my superior officers.  Up, get it? I don't gripe to you, I don't gripe in front of you.  How long you been in the army?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I'm sorry, sir, I apologize.  But if you weren't a captain, or if I were a major, what would you say?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: In addition, as I pointed out earlier, I have a fondness for cheese and I hope to have the opportunity to sample some of the Ramelle products, when we arrive there, to see if they live up to their excellent reputation. Moreover, I feel heartfelt sorrow for the mother of Private James Ryan and I'm more than willing to lay down my life, and the lives of my men, especially you, Reiben, to help relieve her suffering.  The men thoroughly enjoy the performance.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Sir, if you were not a captain, I would compliment you, now, for being an excellent liar.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: But I am a captain.  If I were not a captain, I would thank you for the compliment and tell you that the ability to lie comes from being a top-notch poker player, which I am, having learned at the side of my mother who is, by popular acclaim, the best poker player in...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Any further thoughts on the subject?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Yes, sir, as a final note, I'd like to say, fuck our orders, fuck Ramelle, fuck the cheese capital of France and while we're at it, fuck Private James Ryan.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I'll make a note of your suggestions but I'll leave that last one to you, especially if he's already dead.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Sir, I've got an idea, let's go around.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: We can't leave it here.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Goddamn it...Goddamn it...Goddamn it...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Is silent.  Motionless.  He gently closes Wade's eyes.  His hand quivers slightly as he unclips one of Wades dogtags.  He fumbles and drops it. Sarge notices.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Up.  We're moving out.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I thought you said we had an hour, sir?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Well now I'm saying we're moving out.  Get off your ass.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I've given this a lot of thought, sir.  The best thing that could happen is, we find Ryan and he's dead.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Why's that?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Well, sir, consider the possibilities. A:  Ryan is alive.  We have to take him back to the beach.  Knowing you, you don't let him carry my gear, even though he really should, and we all get killed, trying to keep him alive.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Except for the last part, that one's not bad.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: B:  Ryan is dead.  He's been blown up by the German equivalent of Wade, whose name I know you don't want me to mention.  There's nothing to find. The biggest piece is the size of a pea.  We wander around, looking for him until the Germans pick us off, one after another.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I don't like that one.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Neither do I, sir.  C:  And this is the worst one, we find Ryan and he's wounded.  Not only does he not carry my gear, we have to carry his gear. And him.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: But we accomplish the mission.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Maybe.  But what if he dies on the way back?  you see what I'm saying, sir?  The best possible situation is, he's dead, we find his body, more or less intact, we grab one of his dog-tags and high-tail it back to the beach, or better yet, we head over to Caen and catch up with division.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Has anyone ever told you, you're officer material?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: That's a mystery to me.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Scans the Germans with his binoculars.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Looks like tea time, maybe they're Brits.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Looks like they've been having a hell of a party, here, Captain.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: ON THE BRIDGE!  WE'RE COMING IN.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I HAVE NO FUCKING IDEA.  HERE WE COME.  Cover me.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: What if our guys open up, sir?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You're only allowed to shoot at Germans, that's one of the rules.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Have it your way, Captain.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Yes, sir, of course, sir, I was merely speaking hypothetically.  IF this was a voting situation, then the vote would have been unanimous.  But of course, it's not a voting situation, you're the captain, and you give the orders, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You're goddamned right, I give the order.  Vote!  Jesus Christ!  Listen to me, you little pissant pieces of shit, I am the ranking officer here and what I say goes, is that clear?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Maybe Caen.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Let's hope, because we're sure as hell not going to do any damage to them with what we have here.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Leave him to me, Captain, I'll have him pissing and moaning with the best of us.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: See to it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Cocks his Thompson.  Settles down behind some sandbags.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: HERE THEY COME!

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: OPENS UP with the MACHINE GUN.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Goddamn it...Goddamn it...Goddamn it...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Get back to your positions!

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: What deal?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I coach the baseball team, too.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I wonder if his cabin is still available?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: That's not where I am.  Miller No? Where are you?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Hears the FAINT DISTANT RUMBLE OF THE TANK.  Barely has time to react. Sees:

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Here they come.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: FIRES a burst.  Germans drops.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: FIRES a burst.  More Germans drop.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Continues FIRING.  CUTTING DOWN the advancing Germans.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Knows what that means.  He hears the RUMBLE OF THE TANKS.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Goddamn it!

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: More tanks...  Ryan Lot's of them The fear on their faces turns to resignation.  They know that they are dead men.  They settle into their positions, and prepare to fire and die.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Private.  I'm sorry about your brothers but staying here and getting yourself killed isn't going to help.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Sir, if the Krauts are holding this bridge when division shows up, our guys are going to be sitting ducks.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: This bridge cannot be held.  The Germans have two companies less than three miles from here.  They have tanks.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: The hell you aren't, you're comin' with me if I have to drag you every inch of the way.  You hear me, Private?

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: I hear you sir, but I'm not leaving.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  I want you right next to me, no matter where I go, you understand?

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Alright, come with me.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: I'd like to go, sir.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: No, private, I want you to stay here, keep your head down, don't do anything brave or stupid.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Don't do that again.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: I won't need to sir, it's already here, behind the barricade so...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You set?  Sarge nods.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Is jumped on by one.  Upham FIRES. KILLS the German.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Struggling with a pair of Germans.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Doesn't move.  He just stares at Sarge's body.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Looks at Miller, sees him growing weak, starting to sway.  He gently tries to move Miller aside.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: FIRES THE EIGHTY-EIGHT.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Races through the debris.  Trailed by BULLETS.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yes, Private.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Upham and Jackson, what were they like?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Upham?  Good kid, smart, he was writing a book.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Jackson was from West Fork, Tennessee, he was going to be a preacher, his father and uncles have a traveling ministry out of the back of a stretch Hudson.

turns.speaker: RYAN
turns.text: And Sarge?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Sarge?  He was the best friend I ever had.  Lemme tell you about Sarge...

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: So what?  I've got three satchel charges, six gammon grenades, a dozen- and-a-half pineapples, and all my regular gear.  You don't hear me complaining.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: That's because, as I have pointed out on numerous occasions, you are a happy idiot.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: No, I just happen to take the Captain's advice and look at the bright side of things.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Oh, Christ, now we gotta listen to that grandfather thing again.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: As I was saying, before I was so rudely interrupted, my grandfather got old, as grandfathers tend to do. He needed someone to take care of him.  We move around all the time, going from one mine to another, so we had to put him in a home.  Nice enough place but kind of depressing. But not for Granddad.  He just convinced himself he was on a cruise ship, going to Tahiti, he had his own cabin, first class, with room service.  It just so happened that the weather was always lousy, so he never bothered to go up on deck. Happiest guy you ever saw until the day he died.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Fine, you convince yourself you got a pack full of feathers and goddamned Private James Ryan can carry my fucking gear.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Reiben, you can be very unpleasant to be around sometimes.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: You want unpleasant?  Just wait, I can do much better than this.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Look at Upham, you don't hear him complaining.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Wade's right, it's some kind of scientific, magnetic thing, I can't explain it, but I've seen it.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: We all have, he's got nine lives, or he's bulletproof, or some damn thing.

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Hell, I don't mind this mission, sir, as long as there's something up at Ramelle for...

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: ...for you to blow up, yeah, yeah, we heard that.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Shit, sir.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Fertilizer, Captain, I think we're in a cranberry bog.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Out of the frying pan, into the fucking latrine.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Who cares?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I care.  Don't you know what Caen's famous for, Sarge?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Frogs?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Lingerie.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Yeah?  So?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: I usually like surprises.

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: What are we likely to run into?

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Damn fool.  Sir.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Captain, he's fast!

turns.speaker: SARGE
turns.text: Jesus, Reiben, think of the poor bastard's mother.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Hey, I got a mother.  Jackson, you got a mother?

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: So, where are you from?

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Get lost.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: But everybody's heard of him, he won the Congressional Medal of Honor, he saved a dozen men.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: We know.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Somebody must know where he's from, what he did for a living.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Sir, I ran the 220 in high school.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: He's fast, Captain, I saw him.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: On guard, glancing back.  Pissed off.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: Goddamn it...Goddamn it...Goddamn it...

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Freaked out.  Trying to keep his eyes on the perimeter.  Can't.

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: I don't know, I kind of like Wade's idea about the cruise ship.  I've never been to Tahiti.

turns.speaker: REIBEN
turns.text: What about you, Captain?

turns.speaker: UPHAM
turns.text: Demolition, right?

turns.speaker: WADE
turns.text: Since I was nine years old.  They got a lot of explosives around mines. Me and my little brother could get into any warehouse you ever saw. Damn, we had fun!
